steps: Assess the Situation: Determine the severity of the burn injury.
Cool the Burn: Use cool (not cold) water to cool the burn for at least 10-15 minutes.
Protect the Wound: Cover the burn with a sterile, non-adhesive dressing.
Seek Medical Help: Third-degree burns require professional medical attention.
Monitor and Support: Provide reassurance and emotional support to the person.
requirements: Cool water or clean damp cloth

steps: Clean the Wound: Rinse the cut with clean water to remove dirt and debris.
Apply Pressure: Use a clean cloth or bandage to apply pressure to stop bleeding.
Protect the Wound: Cover the cut with a sterile dressing or bandage.
Seek Medical Help: If the cut is deep or won't stop bleeding, seek medical attention.
Monitor for Infection: Watch for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, or pus.
Apply Ice: Use a cold compress or ice pack wrapped in a cloth to reduce swelling.
Elevate the Area: Raise the bruised area above heart level if possible.
Rest and Protect: Rest the bruised area and protect it from further injury.
Monitor for Complications: Watch for signs of severe pain, numbness, or discoloration.
R.I.C.E Method: Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation.
Rest: Avoid using the injured limb and give it time to heal.
Ice: Apply ice packs wrapped in cloth to reduce swelling and pain.
Compression: Use an elastic bandage to compress the injured area.
Elevation: Elevate the injured limb above heart level when possible.
Immobilize: Keep the injured limb still and in a stable position.
Apply Cold: Use ice packs wrapped in cloth to reduce swelling and pain.
Seek Medical Help: Fractures require professional medical assessment and treatment.
Monitor for Complications: Watch for signs of severe pain, swelling, or numbness.
Stop Bleeding: Apply pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or bandage.
Clean the Wound: Rinse the laceration with clean water to remove dirt and debris.
Protect the Wound: Cover the laceration with a sterile dressing or bandage.
Seek Medical Help: Deep or severe lacerations may require stitches or medical attention.
Monitor for Infection: Watch for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, or pus.
Clean the Wound: Rinse the puncture wound with clean water to remove dirt and debris.
Apply Pressure: Use a clean cloth or bandage to apply pressure to stop bleeding if present.
Protect the Wound: Cover the puncture wound with a sterile dressing or bandage.
Seek Medical Help: Puncture wounds may require medical assessment and tetanus vaccination.
Monitor for Infection: Watch for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, or pus.
Control Bleeding: Apply pressure to the avulsed area to stop bleeding.
Clean the Wound: Rinse the avulsion with clean water to remove dirt and debris.
Preserve Tissue: If possible, save any avulsed tissue in a clean container with saline solution.
Seek Immediate Medical Help: Avulsions often require surgical reattachment and immediate medical attention.
Protect the Wound: Cover the avulsed area with a sterile dressing or bandage.
Clean the Wound: Rinse the abrasion with clean water to remove dirt and debris.
Apply Antibiotic Ointment: Apply a thin layer of antibiotic ointment to prevent infection.
Cover the Wound: Use a sterile dressing or bandage to cover the abrasion.
Monitor for Infection: Watch for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, or pus.
Change Dressing: Change the dressing regularly and keep the abrasion clean and dry.
Control Bleeding: Apply pressure to the amputation site to stop bleeding.
Preserve the Amputated Part: If possible, wrap the amputated part in a clean, damp cloth and place it in a sealed plastic bag.
Seek Immediate Medical Help: Amputations require urgent medical attention and possible surgical intervention.
Protect the Wound: Cover the amputation site with a sterile dressing or bandage.
Monitor for Shock: Watch for signs of shock such as pale skin, rapid heartbeat, and shallow breathing.
